title: Fundraiser accused of spending cash for Lee Rigby's son
text: Share this article Share He is also accused of abusing his position as a trustee and spending funds raised on a music single. After one of the truck-pulling events, where teams of 15 competed to pull lorries fastest, Rebecca said: 'It’s been a great day and it's a great turn-out.' Gardner said: 'It was the biggest party the village had seen for a long time.' The truck-pull events were attended by thousands including the Fusilier's widow Rebecca, 33, and Jack (both right), who was two when Rigby (left) was killed The events in took place in Leicestershire between 2013 and 2015 to raise money for Rigby's son Jack Drummer Rigby, was run over then hacked to death in front of horrified onlookers by Muslim converts Michael Adebolajo, 29, and Michael Adebowale, 22. Last month a conspiracy theorist troll who claimed Lee Rigby's murder was carried out to 'whip up racial hatred' lost his appeal against a conviction for harassing the soldier's family. Christopher Spivey, 54, claimed the murder of Fusilier Rigby was 'staged'. The former builder lost an appeal against a suspended six month jail sentence handed down at Chelmsford Magistrates' Court. During the hearing Spivey, of Rochford, Essex, told a judge at Chelmsford Crown Court: 'It was a fake event allowed to go ahead by the Government, aided by the security services.' Gardener (pictured) also claimed that his charity band Together in Harmony released a 'charity single for ­Fusilier Lee Rigby's son' Gardener (pictured) is accused of abusing his position as a trustee and spending funds raised on a music single Read more: Share or comment on this article 12
